headline.main: In the Region/Connecticut;With Cigars in Vogue, Farmers Return to Tobacco

docs.lead_paragraph: A THREE-YEAR resurgence of cigar smoking has lifted the spirits and lined the pockets of Connecticut's 10 shade tobacco growers, the last of a once-thriving industry that supported hundreds of farmers. But the future of the roughly 2,000 acres of land that they occupy, along with undeveloped land in the north central part of the state, is uncertain. If the farmers continue to prosper, they may retain what they have into the 21st century. If not, a pent-up demand for warehouse and distribution centers by retailers and manufacturers could swallow up whatever is available. Development is on the rise, enhanced by the presence of Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks and highway access to Interstates 91 and 84.

headline.main: The Safety of 2 Classes of Cholesterol-Cutting Drugs Is Debated

keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSN UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: TWO physician-researchers who previously questioned the economic and medical wisdom of universal cholesterol testing and treatment are now questioning the long-term safety of the leading cholesterol-lowering drugs. In an article being published today in The Journal of the American Medical Association, Dr. Thomas B. Newman and Dr. Stephen B. Hulley of the University of California at San Francisco maintain that two classes of drugs, the fibrates and the statins, used by tens of millions of Americans, could possibly cause cancer. But an editorial by two doctors in the journal disputes the thesis.
docs.snippet: TWO physician-researchers who previously questioned the economic and medical  wisdom of universal cholesterol testing and treatment are now questioning the long-term safety of the leading cholesterol-lowering drugs.         In an article being...

docs.lead_paragraph: AMERICANS have a passion for trying to fix things with a pill. Many millions take pills daily to lower their blood pressure or their cholesterol levels. Millions more swallow vitamins and minerals and "nutritional" supplements in the hope of remaining healthy or slowing the progress of disease. And many believe that the pills will somehow render them immune to the damage wrought by unhealthy habits. But others have an aversion to medications or fear their current and possible future side effects, especially drugs that must be taken daily for decades to prevent a health problem that may or may not develop. To avoid taking pills, many of these people change their habits to reduce their risk of disease or premature death. Fifty-two million Americans are candidates for dietary and other changes in habits to lower their cholesterol. Only when that fails to achieve the desired result should drugs be considered.

docs.lead_paragraph: For the cigarette makers, always on the alert for efficient ways to hook new smokers, especially young ones, it was a dandy idea. This was back in the 1870's and 80's, when it wasn't considered right for women to smoke, so the advertising was directed specifically at men and boys. The idea, widely adopted and wildly successful, was to put a picture of a scantily dressed woman inside each pack of cigarettes. It drove adolescent boys into a frenzy. As a study by a team of cancer researchers in California put it: "The early use of 'soft pornography' as the basis for product promotion was reported to have had young boys scrambling after cigarette packs."
